facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 339 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 12, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 436 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 339 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 12, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 436 of 1967. L. Sanghi, and A. G.Ratnaparkhi, for the appellants.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the appeal of the defendants and allowed the cross-objections filed by the respondents on December 12, 1962 in First Appeal No. 436 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated 12th December, 1962 in First Appeal No. 436 of 1958 by which the High Court dismissed the appeal and allowed the cross-objections filed by the respondents in the said appeal.

facts.text: Neneppa II was given in adoption to Goudappa in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Goudappa had one daughter by name Gangabai, while Apparaya had three children i Nenappa II, ii Ravagowda and iii Subhadrabai.In 1930 Nenappa 11 was given in adoption to Goudappa.

facts.text: Revagowda was murdered in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: He had two wives Kashibai and Sidgangawa. Revagowda Married another Sidgangawa. In 1938 Revagowda was murdered.

facts.text: Neneppa II was murdered in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: After Nenappa II was murdered in 1944, both the brothers denied his adoption by Goudappa and purported to effect a partition on 28th April, 1944.

facts.text: Goudappa and Apparaya executed a partition deed on 28th April 1944.

anchor.surface_text: After Nenappa II was murdered in 1944, both the brothers denied his adoption by Goudappa and purported to effect a partition on 28th April, 1944.

facts.text: At the time of death of Neneppa I, joint family owned six plots: survey Nos. 43, 59, 65, 66, 69 in Borgi Khurd (137 acres 15 gunthas, Rs. 126/12/-) and No. 77 in Borgi Budruk (14 acres 24 gunthas, Rs. 16/14/-), total 151 acres 27 gunthas, Rs. 143.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the death of Nenappa 1, six plots of lands belonged to the joint family. Five of these plots are survey Nos. 43, 59, 65, 66 and 69 measuring 137 acres and 15 gunthas and assessed at Rs. 126/12/- and are located in Borgi Khurd.

facts.text: Between 1911 and 1940, 12 other pieces of lands measuring 137 acres 39 gunthas assessed at Rs. 18/10/- were acquired in various names.

anchor.surface_text: Between 1911 and 1940, 12 other pieces of lands in both these villages measuring 137 acres and 39 gunthas and assessed at Rs. 18/10/- were acquired in various names.

facts.text: Plaintiff brought suit on 10th June 1954 challenging the partition deed as fraudulent.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed to be the adopted son of Revagouda and brought the present suit on 10th June, 1954 challenging the partition deed as fraudulent.

facts.text: Defendants contended that partition deed Ex. 157 was genuine and acted upon, and supported all alienations.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants contested the suit on the ground that the partition deed Ex. 157 was a genuine transaction and was acted upon, that Apparaya and Goudappa became separate in status.

facts.text: Trial court held partition deed Ex. 157 not intended to be acted upon, executed to defeat widows' rights; 12 lands joint family property; most alienations not binding except Ex. 159.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court came to the conclusion that the 12 pieces of lands which were acquired between 1911 and 1940 formed part of the joint family properties, that the partition deed Ex. 157 was not intended to be acted upon but was executed to defeat the rights of the widows.

facts.text: Trial court decreed partition with directions.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court accordingly made a decree for partition with appropriate directions.

facts.text: High Court on 12th December 1962 dismissed defendants' appeal and allowed plaintiff's cross-objection holding Ex. 159 not binding.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated 12th December, 1962, the High Court dismissed the appeal of the defendants and allowed the cross-objection of the plaintiff holding that the sale-deed Ex. 159 regarding survey plots Nos. 43 and 77 was also not binding upon the plaintiff.

facts.text: Both trial court and High Court found partition deed not genuine, effected to defeat widows' rights.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial court and the High Court have reached a concurrent finding after an elaborate examination of the evidence that the partition deed was not genuine, and that it was effected for an ulterior purpose.

facts.text: Goudappa gifted S. Nos. 61 and 62 of Borgi Budruk and Survey No. 45 of Borgi Khurd to defendant No. 4 Subhadrabai by Ex. 161 on 25th September 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On 25th September, 1944 by Ex. 161 Goudappa gifted S. Nos. 61 and 62 of Borgi Budruk and Survey No. 45 of Borgi Khurd to defendant No. 4, Subhadrabai.

facts.text: Goudappa gifted survey Nos. 62 and 63 of Borgi Khurd and Survey No. 11/3 of Borgi Budruk to defendant No. 3 by Ex. 162 dated 1st October 1946.

anchor.surface_text: By Ex. 162, dated 1st October, 1946 Goudappa made a gift of plot survey Nos. 62 and 63 of Borgi Khurd and Survey No. 11/3 of Borgi Budruk to defendant No. 3 who is the daughter of Nenappa H.

facts.text: Apparaya sold survey Nos. 77 and 43 to defendant No. 3 for Rs. 5000 by Ex. 159 on 20th April 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On 20th April, 1948 by Ex. 159 Apparaya sold survey Nos. 77 and 43 to defendant No. 3 for a sum of Rs. 50001.

facts.text: Goudappa sold survey No. 79 to Apparaya for Rs. 1000 by Ex. 160 on 20th April 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day by Ex. 160 Goudappa sold survey No. 79 for Rs. 1,000/- to Apparaya.

facts.text: Courts found adequate nucleus of joint family property: 151 acres 27 gunthas assessed at Rs. 143 at Neneppa I's death.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that when Nenappa I died, the joint family was possessed of 151 acres and 27 gunthas of land assessed at Rs. 143.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld concurrent finding that partition was sham and not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the finding of the lower courts upon this question is essentially a finding upon a question of fact, and in an appeal by special leave it is the normal practice of this Court to accept such a concurrent finding of fact as correct.

facts.text: 12 pieces of lands acquired 1911-1940 are joint family properties as per both lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Both the lower courts have found that there was an adequate nucleus of joint family properties from which the acquisitions could have been made.

facts.text: Sigangawa I died on 20-12-1953.

anchor.surface_text: Neneppa Gowdwppa1. Kashibai ApparayaSidgangawa II Sigangawa I died on 20-12-53 Widows of Gowdappa wife of Apparaya time of Apparaya

facts.text: Plaintiff is the adopted son of Revagowda.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed to be the adopted son of Revagouda and brought the present suit on 10th June, 1954 challenging the partition deed as fraudulent.

facts.text: After partition deed, brothers continued joint possession and lived jointly.

anchor.surface_text: There is also evidence that after the partition deed, the two brothers continued to be in joint possession of the lands and they lived joint in the same house as before.

facts.text: High Court held sale Ex. 159 without consideration and not genuine as defendant No. 3 was minor, Goudappa her guardian.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out that defendant No. 3 was a minor at the time of sale, that Goudappa had acted as her guardian and that defendant No. 3 had no property of her own.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 12, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 436 of 1967. L. Sanghi, and A. G.Ratnaparkhi, for the appellants.

Both the trial court and the High Court have reached a concurrent finding after an elaborate examination of the evidence that the partition deed was not genuine, and that it was effected for an ulterior purpose in order to defeat the rights of the widows in the joint family. It is manifest that the finding of the lower courts upon this question is essentially a finding upon a question of fact, and in an appeal by special leave it is the normal practice of this Court to accept such a concurrent finding of fact as correct.

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court accepts concurrent findings of lower courts on questions of fact in special leave appeals.

concepts.unlisted_label: Concurrent Findings of Fact in Special Leave Appeals
concepts.unlisted_description: Practice of not disturbing concurrent factual findings by lower courts in Article 136 appeals.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated 12th December, 1962, the High Court dismissed the appeal of the defendants and allowed the cross-objection of the. plaintiff holding that the sale-deed Ex. 159 regarding survey plots Nos. 43 and 77 was also not binding upon the plaintiff. The first question to be considered-in this appeal is whether the partition. deed executed by Goudappa and Apparaya on 28th April, 1944 was a sham transaction and not intended to be effective.

concepts.interpretation: Partition deed not genuine if executed for ulterior purpose like defeating widows' rights and not acted upon.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: to Apparaya is Rs. 61/7/-. There appears to be nu

concepts.unlisted_description: Partition deed intended only to defeat claims (e.g., widows' maintenance) and not acted upon does not bind joint family.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well established that an agreement between all the coparceners is not essential to the disruption of the joint family status, but a definite and unambiguous indication of intention by one member to separate himself from the family and to enjoy his share in severalty will amount in law to a division of status. It is immaterial in such a case whether the other members assent or not.

concepts.interpretation: Sham expression of intention does not sever joint status; requires definite, unequivocal, and genuine indication communicated to co-sharers.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: -the family members. Between 1911 and 1940 12 other pieces of lands measuring 137 acres and 39 gunthas assessed at Rs. 18/10/- were acquired in variou

concepts.unlisted_description: Unequivocal intention to separate by one coparcener suffices for severance, even without agreement; pretence or sham ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: It was at one time supposed that the doctrine of Mitakshara law was that if the last surviving coparcener died and the property passed to his heir, such as a widow or a collateral, the power of the widow of a predeceased coparcener to. adopt was at an end. Chandra v. Gojarabai and Adivi Suryapnakasarao v. Nidamarty Gangaraju  2 . The cases on this point were considered in 1936 by the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Balu Sakharam Powar v.

concepts.interpretation: Overruled view; widow's power to adopt continues post death of last coparcener or partition; cannot be defeated thereby.

concepts.unlisted_label: Hindu Widow's Power to Adopt (Mitakshara Law)
concepts.unlisted_description: Widow of predeceased coparcener retains adoption power despite coparcenary ending by death or partition.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the adopted son relate back to the date of the adoptive fathers death and the adopted son must be deemed by a fiction of law to have been in existence as the son of the adoptive father at the time of the latters death. If, therefore, there was a coparcenary in existence when the adoptive father then whether it came to an end by the death of the last surviving coparcener or by subsequent partition among the remaining members, an adoption validly made by the widow of the deceased coparcener would have the effect of divesting the estate in the hands of the heir to the last surviving coparcener in the first case and of putting an end to the partition in the second case and enabling the adopted son to claim a share in the family properties as if they were still joint.

concepts.interpretation: Valid adoption by widow divests estate vested in last coparcener's heir or reopens partition, bringing adopted son into coparcenary ab initio.

concepts.unlisted_description: Adopted son's rights relate back to adoptive father's death, reviving coparcenary or divesting post-death partitions/vestings.

concepts.interpretation: Adequate nucleus (151 acres assessed Rs.143) presumes 12 lands (137 acres, Rs.4800 over 30 yrs) joint absent proof of separate acquisition source.
concepts.unlisted_label: Presumption from Nucleus of Joint Family Property
concepts.unlisted_description: Joint nucleus shifts burden to prove self-acquisition without family aid; no general presumption of jointness.

concepts.interpretation: Sale by de facto guardian on behalf of minor without consideration and when minor had no funds is invalid and not binding.
concepts.unlisted_label: Invalidity of De Facto Guardian's Sale Without Consideration
concepts.unlisted_description: Guardian's alienation of minor's property lacking consideration, especially sans minor's resources, deemed not genuine.

holdings.text: The partition deed executed by Goudappa and Apparaya on 28th April, 1944 was a sham transaction and not intended to be effective.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered-in this appeal is whether the partition. deed executed by Goudappa and Apparaya on 28th April, 1944 was a sham transaction and number intended to be effective. Both the trial court and the High Court have reached a concurrent finding after an elaborate examination of the evidence that the partition deed was number genuine, and that it was effected for an ulterior purpose in order to defeat the rights of the widows in the joint family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent factual finding of lower courts upheld in special leave appeal; supported by evidence of no panchas, unequal division, no house mention, continued joint possession and mess, motive to defeat widows' adoption rights.

holdings.text: Even though the partition deed was bogus there was no severance of joint family status and the family continued to be joint after 28th April 1944.

anchor.surface_text: it was also contended on behalf of the appellants that even though the partition deed was bogus there was in law a severance of joint family status and the family could number continue to be joint after 20th April, 1944 which was the date of the partition deed. In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sham or pretence does not amount to definite and unequivocal intention to separate required for severance of status; cites Merla Ramanna v. Chelikani.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the 12 pieces of lands were joint family properties and were not the self acquisition of Goudappa.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Adequate nucleus of joint property (151 acres assessed Rs.143, income Rs.5000-6000) presumes acquisitions joint; appellants failed to prove separate source; cites Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurti.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in allowing the cross-objection holding sale-deed Ex. 159 not binding on plaintiff.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale by de facto guardian (Goudappa) for minor defendant No.3 without consideration or her own funds invalid; challenged in plaint schedule.

holdings.text: The judgment of the Bombay High Court dated 12th December, 1962 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All issues resolved in favor of respondents upholding lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Chandra v. Gojarabai

precedents.cited_proposition: doctrine of Mitakshara law was that if the last surviving coparcener died and the property passed to his heir, such as a widow or a collateral, the power of the widow of a predeceased coparcener to adopt was at an end

anchor.surface_text: Adivi Suryapnakasarao v. Nidamarty Gangaraju 2

precedents.cited_proposition: doctrine of Mitakshara law was that if the last surviving coparcener died and the property passed to his heir, such as a widow or a collateral, the power of the widow of a predeceased coparcener to adopt was at an end

precedents.citation: Balu Sakharam Powar v. Lahoo Sambhaji Tetgura 3

anchor.surface_text: Balu Sakharam Powar v. Lahoo Sambhaji Tetgura 3

precedents.case_name: Balu Sakharam Powar v Lahoo Sambhaji Tetgura
precedents.cited_proposition: where a coparcenary exists at the date of the adoption the adopted son becomes a member of the coparcenary, and takes his share in the joint property, but where the partition takes place after the termination of the coparcenary by the death, actually or fictionally, of the last surviving coparcener, the adoption by a widow of a deceased coparcener has not the effect of reviving the coparcenary and does not divest property from the heir of the last surviving coparcener other than the widow or those claiming through him or her
precedents.cited_holding: adoption by widow does not revive coparcenary or divest heir after death of last coparcener

anchor.surface_text: Anant V. Shankar 4

precedents.cited_proposition: the power of a Hindu widow does not come to an end on the death of the sole surviving coparcener. Neither does it depend upon the vesting or divesting of the estate, nor can the right to adopt be defeated by partition between the coparceners. The rights of the adopted son relate back to the date of the adoptive fathers death and the adopted son must be deemed by a fiction of law to have been in existence as the son of the adoptive father at the time of the latters death. If, therefore, there was a coparcenary in existence when the adoptive father died whether it came to an end by the death of the last surviving coparcener or by subsequent partition among the remaining members, an adoption validly made by the widow of the deceased coparcener would have the effect of divesting the estate in the hands of the heir to the last surviving coparcener in the first case and of putting an end to the partition in the second case and enabling the adopted son to claim a share in the family properties as if they were still joint
precedents.cited_holding: power of Hindu widow to adopt continues after death of sole surviving coparcener; adoption relates back and divests estate or reunites partitioned property

precedents.citation: Merla Ramanna v. Chelikani Jagannadha Rao Ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: Merla Ramanna v. Chelikani Jagannadha Rao Ors. 1

precedents.case_name: Merla Ramanna v Chelikani Jagannadha Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: in order to operate as a severance of joint status, it is necessary that the expression of intention by the member separating himself from the joint family must be definite and unequivocal. If, however, the expression of intention is a mere pretence or a sham, there is in the eye of law no separation of the joint family status
precedents.cited_holding: sham or pretence of intention to separate does not effect severance of joint status

anchor.surface_text: Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurti 2

precedents.cited_proposition: Proof of the existence of a joint family does not lead to the presumption that property held by any member of the family is joint, and the burden rests upon anyone asserting that any item of property was joint to establish the fact. But where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may have been acquired, the burden shifts to the party alleging self-acquisition to establish affirmatively that the property was acquired without the aid of the joint family property
precedents.cited_holding: if nucleus of joint property proved, acquisitions presumed joint unless proved otherwise without aid

anchor.surface_text: Babubhai Girdharlal v. Ujamlal Hargovandas 1

precedents.cited_proposition: where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may have been acquired, the burden shifts to the party alleging self-acquisition to establish affirmatively that the property was acquired without the aid of the joint family property

anchor.surface_text: Venkataramayya v. Seshamma 2

precedents.cited_proposition: where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may have been acquired, the burden shifts to the party alleging self-acquisition to establish affirmatively that the property was acquired without the aid of the joint family property

anchor.surface_text: Vythianatha v. Varadaraja 3

precedents.cited_proposition: where it is established that the family possessed some joint property which from its nature and relative value may have formed the nucleus from which the property in question may have been acquired, the burden shifts to the party alleging self-acquisition to establish affirmatively that the property was acquired without the aid of the joint family property

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered-in this appeal is whether the partition. deed executed by Goudappa and Apparaya on 28th April, 1944 was a sham transaction and number intended to be effective. Both the trial court and the High Court have reached a concurrent finding after an elaborate examination of the evidence that the partition deed was number genuine, and that it was effected for an ulterior purpose in order to defeat the rights of the widows in the joint family.
For these reasons we hold that the, judgment of the Bombay High Court dated 12th December, 1962 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: it was also contended on behalf of the appellants that even though the partition deed was bogus there was in law a severance of joint family status and the family could number continue to be joint after 20th April, 1944 which was the date of the partition deed. In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this argument.
For these reasons we hold that the, judgment of the Bombay High Court dated 12th December, 1962 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.
